description: The user asks to temporarily add the interest keyword “quantum computing” to their news digest and see the top ranked articles that would appear in tomorrow’s email. The assistant updates the user profile, fetches RSS feeds, extracts and summarizes articles, ranks them against the updated profile, and presents the preview of the next day’s digest.

messages.content: You are a helpful assistant for a Personalized News Digest service. You can fetch RSS feeds, extract article content, summarize articles, rank them based on a user’s interest profile, update the profile, and send email digests. Respond in a friendly tone and show the results of any tool calls to the user.
I'd like to test a new interest keyword – "quantum computing" – for my news digest. Please add it temporarily and show me what the top articles would look like in tomorrow’s ranking.

Got it! I’ll add **quantum computing** to your interest profile for this preview, pull the latest articles from a few tech‑focused RSS feeds, summarize them, rank the summaries against your updated profile, and then show you the top five articles that would appear in tomorrow’s email.

(Executing the required tool calls…)
{"status":"success","message":"Profile updated for user alice@example.com with topics: artificial intelligence, software development, quantum computing."}

[{"title":"Google announces new quantum‑supremacy experiment","link":"https://arstechnica.com/tech/2025/12/google-quantum-supremacy-2025","publish_date":"2025-12-06"},{"title":"Breakthrough in error‑corrected quantum bits","link":"https://www.sciencemag.org/content/quantum-error-correction-2025","publish_date":"2025-12-05"},{"title":"Microsoft Edge adds AI‑driven code suggestions","link":"https://www.techmeme.com/2025-12-06/microsoft-edge-ai-code","publish_date":"2025-12-06"}]
I’ve retrieved three recent articles from the selected feeds. Now I’ll pull the full content for each article and create concise summaries.

Full article text: "Google’s Quantum AI team has unveiled a new quantum‑supremacy experiment that solves a specific Monte‑Carlo sampling problem 10,000 times faster than the best classical supercomputer. The experiment uses a 256‑qubit Sycamore processor with novel error‑mitigation techniques…"

Full article text: "Researchers at MIT and IBM report a breakthrough in error‑corrected qubits, demonstrating a logical qubit that retains coherence for over 1 millisecond. This achievement marks a critical step toward scalable fault‑tolerant quantum computers…"

Full article text: "Microsoft Edge now includes an AI‑driven code suggestion feature called EdgeDev Copilot. The tool leverages a large language model trained on open‑source repositories to offer context‑aware snippets as developers write JavaScript, Python, and TypeScript…"
Summarizing each article with a focus on your interests:

arguments.text: Google’s Quantum AI team has unveiled a new quantum‑supremacy experiment that solves a specific Monte‑Carlo sampling problem 10,000 times faster than the best classical supercomputer. The experiment uses a 256‑qubit Sycamore processor with novel error‑mitigation techniques…

Researchers at MIT and IBM report a breakthrough in error‑corrected qubits, demonstrating a logical qubit that retains coherence for over 1 millisecond. This achievement marks a critical step toward scalable fault‑tolerant quantum computers…

Microsoft Edge now includes an AI‑driven code suggestion feature called EdgeDev Copilot. The tool leverages a large language model trained on open‑source repositories to offer context‑aware snippets as developers write JavaScript, Python, and TypeScript…

messages.content: Summary: Google announced a new quantum‑supremacy experiment using its 256‑qubit Sycamore processor, achieving a speed‑up of 10,000× on a Monte‑Carlo sampling task. The breakthrough includes advanced error‑mitigation methods, positioning Google at the forefront of practical quantum computing.

Summary: MIT and IBM researchers demonstrated an error‑corrected logical qubit that holds coherence for more than 1 ms, a major milestone toward fault‑tolerant quantum computers. This result showcases a scalable path for building larger quantum processors.

Summary: Microsoft Edge introduced EdgeDev Copilot, an AI‑powered code suggestion tool that provides context‑aware snippets for JavaScript, Python, and TypeScript. While not directly related to quantum computing, it reflects broader AI developments in developer tools.
Now I’ll rank these summaries against your updated interest profile (which now includes *quantum computing*).

summaries: Google announced a new quantum‑supremacy experiment using its 256‑qubit Sycamore processor, achieving a speed‑up of 10,000× on a Monte‑Carlo sampling task. The breakthrough includes advanced error‑mitigation methods, positioning Google at the forefront of practical quantum computing.

MIT and IBM researchers demonstrated an error‑corrected logical qubit that holds coherence for more than 1 ms, a major milestone toward fault‑tolerant quantum computers. This result showcases a scalable path for building larger quantum processors.

Microsoft Edge introduced EdgeDev Copilot, an AI‑powered code suggestion tool that provides context‑aware snippets for JavaScript, Python, and TypeScript. While not directly related to quantum computing, it reflects broader AI developments in developer tools.

This result showcases a scalable path for building larger quantum processors.","title":"Breakthrough in error‑corrected quantum bits","link":"https://www.sciencemag.org/content/quantum-error-correction-2025"},{"summary":"Google announced a new quantum‑supremacy experiment using its 256‑qubit Sycamore processor, achieving a speed‑up of 10,000× on a Monte‑Carlo sampling task. The breakthrough includes advanced error‑mitigation methods, positioning Google at the forefront of practical quantum computing.","title":"Google announces new quantum‑supremacy experiment","link":"https://arstechnica.com/tech/2025/12/google-quantum-supremacy-2025"}]

Here’s a preview of the top articles that would appear in tomorrow’s digest, based on your temporary interest in **quantum computing**:

1. **Breakthrough in error‑corrected quantum bits**
   *Source:* Science Magazine
   *Link:* https://www.sciencemag.org/content/quantum-error-correction-2025
   *Summary:* MIT and IBM researchers demonstrated an error‑corrected logical qubit that holds coherence for more than 1 ms, a major milestone toward fault‑tolerant quantum computers. This result showcases a scalable path for building larger quantum processors.

2. **Google announces new quantum‑supremacy experiment**
   *Source:* Ars Technica
   *Link:* https://arstechnica.com/tech/2025/12/google-quantum-supremacy-2025
   *Summary:* Google announced a new quantum‑supremacy experiment using its 256‑qubit Sycamore processor, achieving a speed‑up of 10,000× on a Monte‑Carlo sampling task. The breakthrough includes advanced error‑mitigation methods, positioning Google at the forefront of practical quantum computing.

*(Other articles, like the EdgeDev Copilot announcement, were less relevant to your quantum‑computing interest and therefore didn’t make the top‑5 list.)*

Would you like to keep **quantum computing** in your permanent profile, or should I remove it after this preview?
